stream_context.summary: Kaze begins early art-direction and layout planning for Course 12, a Western/cowboy-themed level. He iterates on building textures/colors, discovers that the skybox/fog drastically changes the look, and settles toward a blue-sky/blue-fog direction supported by new music from Badub. He then starts an MS-Paint-style top-down town plan designed for strong first-time player onboarding and N64-friendly culling (a circular town wrapped around a central mountain), while outlining three “outlaw” mini-boss stars (saloon shootout, bank-robber Monty Mole trail, and a train-robbery Goomba gag).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces Course 12’s full fantasy (cowboyaboo tone), defines its mission structure (three outlaw stars + area 2 scavenger hunt), and makes several project-relevant technical/art decisions (Fast64 workflow, fog = 2-cycle performance cost, central-mountain layout for culling) while integrating a new Badub music track that influences the visual direction.

findings.summary: Course 12 is a Western town/canyon valley built around “catching outlaws” and jailing them; Kaze plans three small boss encounters, each awarding a star, and each thematically tied to town locations (saloon, bank, train).

Planned mission concepts: (1) saloon secret room leads to a shootout with an outlaw Snufit; (2) Monty Mole bank robbery solved by following a continuous ground trail into a hideout and then a boss fight; (3) train robbery mystery where a tall “suspicious” Goomba in a trench coat is actually five Goombas that split into a shootout-style fight.

The level is structured as three connected areas: Area 1 town, Area 2 valley/traversal “playground” (also a scavenger-hunt star using signpost hints), and Area 3 train headquarters/gold-mine zone; the train provides fast travel between Area 1 and Area 3.

NPC tone direction: the town’s friendly NPCs will be “Yoshi cowboys” (and/or cowboy Toads), all speaking in exaggerated “howdy partner” Western slang; the saloon is a comedic centerpiece where everyone drinks milk, with dialogue inspired by the ‘Cowboy Cats’ account.

Kaze explicitly rejects adding references he doesn’t understand or enjoy, and avoids pushing the train into an ‘investigation roleplay’ idea if it doesn’t fit Mario 64’s mission format; he also states Course 12 won’t be built around an overarching story/time-progression act structure.
findings.quote: It doesn’t fit Mario 64… There’s no story, we can’t do a time progression. It’s just a bunch of disconnected missions.

findings.summary: Kaze’s level pipeline is Blender + Fast64 exporting directly into the Mario 64 decomp project; he does not currently have tutorials available because Nintendo removed his previous tutorial content.
findings.quote: There’s a plugin called Fast64. You can just export levels from it into Decomp. I don’t explain this anywhere. Nintendo took all my tutorials down.

findings.summary: Fog is a major visual target for the cowboy canyon mood, but enabling it widely forces 2-cycle materials, which Kaze calls “really, really bad” for performance; he notes they already hit this tradeoff in Oily Boily Bay and may need to accept the cost if the look is worth it.
findings.quote: Unfortunately, this means everything is going to be a 2-cycle material. Which is really, really bad. We’ve already experienced this in Oily Boily Bay.

findings.summary: A key art-direction breakthrough is realizing the sky/atmosphere must be chosen early; after adding a skybox and testing blue vs orange fog, Kaze strongly prefers the blue fog look (especially paired with Badub’s music), and decides the style is good enough to proceed to layout mapping.
findings.quote: This changes the vibe so much… Obviously actually, I should have figured to do the sky first.

findings.summary: He uses F3DEX3 (but says he’s on a “really old version”) and mentions common N64 aesthetic constraints like keeping textures around 64x64 to stay within the classic look/performance envelope.
findings.quote: Of course I’m using F3DEX3. Well, I’m using a really old version.

findings.summary: Town layout is being designed for both readability and N64 culling: Kaze plans a circular/‘reverse donut’ town wrapped around a central mountain so distant geometry can be hidden, and he wants Mario’s spawn framed so the jail (objective briefing) is directly in view immediately.
findings.quote: So what if this whole city was kind of around a mountain? That would work well for the N64. Because of how much culling it allows.

findings.summary: Train presence is a recurring set-piece: Kaze wants the player to see the train pass overhead near the start and is exploring sky-elevated tracks (inspired by Wario’s Gold Mine) to make traversal less boring than a long tunnel, even if ‘floating tracks’ are slightly surreal.
findings.quote: This is not about logic. This is about cool. Rule of cool.

findings.summary: Kaze says overall development slowed after Course 9 because he now has a full-time job, affecting pace and likely the cadence of major course completions.
findings.quote: Development has slowed down ever since the end of course 9, because I have a full-time job now.

biobak.summary: Biobak pushes visual inspiration from other sources (including a suggestion to look at/‘steal’ a look from another game/level), which leads Kaze to interpret the feedback as a saturation/palette discussion and re-check Twilight Princess-style town references.
Biobak previously remarked that Kaze’s colorful town direction reads like Odyssey (Kaze repeats this while evaluating whether the palette still feels ‘Mario-like’ for SM64).

badub.summary: Badub DMs Kaze a fresh Course 12 music track mid-stream; Kaze assumes it was composed specifically for this cowboy level and reacts very positively, then uses the track to sanity-check the level’s intended mood (fog/sky decisions).
badub.quote: Oh, that’s so perfect. I love this… I’m assuming he made this for this level.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly appears off-mic/at home during the stream; no direct development decision is attributed to her in this transcript segment.

findings.summary: Lilaa gives moment-to-moment visual feedback (e.g., comparing prior fences and suggesting style elements), prompting Kaze to consider reusing a more ‘3D’ fence approach he liked in earlier work.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There’s a plugin called Fast64. You can just export levels from it into Decomp. I don’t explain this anywhere. Nintendo took all my tutorials down.
memorable_quotes.context: Concrete statement about the team’s toolchain and the impact of Nintendo takedowns on knowledge-sharing/documentation.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This is not about logic. This is about cool. Rule of cool.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze frames a key design principle while deciding how to justify traversal/track placement and set-piece spectacle on N64.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I want it to be that, but for cowboys… So, a cowboyaboo.
memorable_quotes.context: Defines the intended tone: intentionally exaggerated, affectionate parody of Western tropes (important for documentary theme of ‘respectful remix’ vs satire).

key_stories.title: Finding Course 12’s art direction by starting with atmosphere
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles to make Western buildings ‘pop’ against an orange canyon/sand base without becoming monochrome or “color vomit.” A major shift happens when he adds a skybox and tests fog colors; the overall scene suddenly feels cohesive, especially once Badub’s music arrives and reinforces a hazy canyon mood.
key_stories.challenge: The Western town reads flat/ugly with early building textures and inconsistent palette; buildings don’t stand out and the vibe isn’t the intended goofy cowboy comedy.
key_stories.process: He cycles through reference boards (Twilight Princess hidden village, Yoshi Valley/Mario Party Western Land, other games), tests saturation/contrast changes, then prioritizes skybox + fog experiments (blue vs orange). He evaluates visuals in-game rather than in isolation and cross-checks the mood against the new music track.
key_stories.outcome: He prefers the blue-fog look and declares the style “good to go,” moving to the next production step: an overhead MS Paint map and blockout planning.
key_stories.key_quote: This changes the vibe so much… Obviously actually, I should have figured to do the sky first.

key_stories.title: Fog as a visual win with a performance tax
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements fog (via Fast64/global fog) to sell depth and atmosphere in the canyon town, but runs into a known N64 constraint: widespread fog pushes materials into 2-cycle rendering. He recalls similar pain from Oily Boily Bay and weighs taking the performance hit if the look is strong enough.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve Western haze/depth while staying within N64 rendering performance limits.
key_stories.process: He attempts fog setup, diagnoses why it isn’t appearing, then sets fog through a dedicated ‘fog triangle/material’ approach he uses in other levels. He notes fog can’t be used the way chat suggests (e.g., for culling) and that it can worsen performance.
key_stories.outcome: Fog is working visually, but the 2-cycle requirement becomes the new constraint to manage during later optimization and material planning.
key_stories.key_quote: It might just look so good that we have to take the loss.

open_questions.topic: Lost tutorials and internal documentation after Nintendo takedowns
open_questions.context: Kaze says his Fast64/decomp tutorials were taken down by Nintendo, and he currently doesn’t explain the toolchain publicly.
questions: What exactly happened with the tutorial takedowns (which videos, when, what claims), and how did it change the team/community pipeline for onboarding new contributors?
Did the takedowns push the team toward private docs, Discord knowledge, or direct mentorship—who maintains that knowledge now?
What parts of the pipeline are most fragile without video documentation (Fast64 export settings, collision, material setup, fog triangle conventions, etc.)?

open_questions.context: Kaze observes that fog forces 2-cycle materials and calls it “really, really bad,” referencing prior experience in Oily Boily Bay.
questions: What were the concrete symptoms in Oily Boily Bay (FPS drops, RSP/RDP time, specific scenes/materials) and what fixes were attempted?
For Course 12, will fog be limited to specific geometry/material categories, or will you accept 2-cycle broadly and optimize elsewhere (tri counts, draw calls, texture sizes)?
Are there alternative atmosphere tricks you’ve used or considered (gradient skybox, vertex lighting tricks, dither patterns, selective fog volumes) that avoid 2-cycle everywhere?
How does your current (old) F3DEX3 version affect fog/material options—was upgrading considered?

open_questions.topic: Course 12 mission pacing and onboarding choice (jail as first sightline)
open_questions.context: Kaze wants Mario to spawn facing the jail so the player immediately gets the roleplay premise and doesn’t miss the briefing.
questions: How often do you design starts around forced sightlines vs player freedom, and what did you learn from earlier courses about players missing key NPCs or objectives?
What’s the intended emotional beat for the first 30 seconds—comedy, spectacle (train overhead), or clarity of mission goals—and which gets priority if they conflict?
Will the jail briefing be skippable/rediscoverable, and how do you prevent confusion in a ‘disconnected missions’ structure?

open_questions.topic: Train traversal design: permanent set-piece vs player-controlled fast travel
open_questions.context: Kaze wants the train to have a visible presence and is exploring sky tracks to avoid boring tunnels; the train also fast travels between Area 1 and Area 3.
questions: Will the train be purely a warp/rideable vehicle on a fixed schedule, or can players miss it and wait—how will timing and frustration be handled?
What technical approach will drive the train (path spline, segmented motion, collision, camera behavior), and what are the hardest N64 constraints (collision on moving platforms, culling, audio)?
How do you balance ‘train as spectacle’ with ‘train as utility’ so it feels iconic but not mandatory for completion?
What made you abandon the train-tunnel idea—was it primarily gameplay monotony, rendering/camera issues, or both?

open_questions.context: Badub’s cowboy track arrives mid-stream and immediately influences Kaze’s atmosphere decisions (fog/sky mood).
questions: How often does music arrive early enough to shape level visuals/gameplay (like here), vs being composed to match a finished level?
What direction did you give Badub for this track (references, tempo, instruments), and what did he infer on his own?
Do you iterate together (Kaze requests revisions) or is it mostly ‘deliver and accept’—and what’s the best example of a track changing a level design decision?
